entry.title: What's New in SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2 Analytics - October 2025
entry.content:
As part of our September 2025 release, we are excited to introduce a major innovation in Analytics across SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2 and SAP Enterprise Service Management solutions: Intent-Based Navigation. This new capability enhances the way business users move from insight to action by seamlessly connecting embedded analytics with operational user interfaces.

A More Intuitive Path From Story to Action

Intent-Based Navigation allows business users to jump directly from an Embedded SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) story to the corresponding UI instance of a business entity. With a couple of clicks, users can transition from analytical context to the exact object instance they need to review or update—streamlining workflows and improving decision-making.

It is important to note that this capability is designed specifically for business users consuming embedded stories. Stories opened through the Design Stories environment for analytics administrators will not have this feature.

For full technical details, you can explore the feature in our online Help documentation here - https://help.sap.com/docs/CX_NG_SALES/ea5ff8b9460a43cb8765a3c07d3421fe/0b8c99cff1604ede87f109026d018344.html#loio476fee7e5d5d434194f3a7f30ddc86d2

A short demo is also available showcasing the experience end-to-end here - https://sapvideo.cfapps.eu10-004.hana.ondemand.com/?entry_id=1_f0xp7m42

Key Behavior: Navigation Works on Key Fields

As demonstrated in the demo, navigation is available only for key fields such as ID or Display ID. Because the feature is intended to take users to a specific object instance, non-key fields—such as dates, statuses, and other descriptive attributes—do not enable the Jump-To option.

What’s Coming Next

We are actively working on extending navigation capabilities. Upcoming enhancements will include:

  • Navigating from an Embedded SAC story to another SAC story
  • Jumping from non-key fields to a filtered List UI of the corresponding business entity

These additions will further enrich cross-application navigation and analytical usability in future releases.

entry.title: Slaying the S/4 HANA Dual Maintenance & interim State Monster: Palantir's Trick to Treat Your Budget
entry.content:
INTRODUCTION

Imagine trying to rebuild your entire house, from the foundations up, while still living in it and running your daily life! That's the scale of the challenge many global enterprises are embracing as they transition from SAP ECC to S/4HANA. It's not just a tech upgrade; it's arguably the most significant transformation they'll undertake this decade.

Given the sheer size, the intricate sap integration web of operations with other systems, and all those unique regional needs, no one wants to risk bringing their business to a standstill. That's why most organisations are wisely choosing a thoughtful, multi-year, phased rollout.

Migrating from SAP ECC to S/4HANA is one of the most significant transformations many global enterprises will undertake this decade. Given the scale, complexity, and regional dependencies involved, most organizations opt for a multi-year, phased rollout to minimize business disruption.

While this approach minimizes business disruption, it introduces a costly challenge: dual maintenance the need to maintain, reconcile, and synchronize data and processes across both ECC and S/4 systems during the transition period.

In this post, we’ll explore how Palantir’s data integration and digital twin capabilities can dramatically reduce those interim costs, streamline operations, and accelerate time-to-value.

The Dual Maintenance Dilemma

During a staggered rollout, some business units run on ECC while others move to S/4HANA. This creates temporary but expensive complexity:

  • Duplicate data maintenance across ECC and S/4 systems (e.g., master data, pricing conditions, bills of material)

  • Parallel reporting landscapes, as analytics must draw from both systems

  • Integration bridges required to maintain end-to-end process continuity (order-to-cash, procure-to-pay, etc.)

  • Reconciliation overhead to ensure financial and operational consistency

These efforts can add millions in IT and business costs annually during the rollout.

What Palantir does differently for Interim State?

Rapid Data Integration: Foundry excels at ingesting and integrating vast amounts of disparate data (structured, unstructured, streaming) from various source systems (legacy databases, cloud applications, IoT devices, spreadsheets, etc.) into a single, coherent data asset. This significantly reduces the need for manual data manipulation or temporary data warehouses.

Dynamic Data Models (Ontology): Instead of static data models, Foundry builds a dynamic "ontology" , a living, interconnected representation of an organisation's real-world entities (e.g., customers, assets, products, events) and their relationships. This provides a unified, real-time "digital twin" of the organisation's operations. This eliminates the "interim state" of fragmented data views and manual reconciliation.

Data Lineage and Governance: Foundry automatically tracks data lineage, providing transparency on where data comes from and how it's transformed. This builds trust in the data and reduces the need for manual validation steps often found in interim processes.

Accelerated Application Development: Users can build operational applications, dashboards, and analytical tools directly on top of this integrated ontology without needing to move data to separate systems. This bypasses the need for bespoke, temporary solutions that often characterise an interim state.

System of Engagement over System of Record": Palantir often acts as a "system of engagement" or "system of analysis" that sits on top of existing "systems of record." It doesn't require organisations to immediately rip and replace their legacy systems. Instead, it integrates data from these systems, allowing them to continue functioning while providing a modern, unified operational layer.

In essence, Palantir Foundry's unique value lies in its ability to rapidly integrate and harmonise data from across an enterprise into a dynamic, operational ontology. This provides a single, coherent source of truth and a platform for building applications, thereby eliminating the need for costly "interim states" and allowing organisations to strategically reduce or retire redundant systems, thus cutting "dual maintenance running costs".

Palantir: A Unified Data and Process Layer

Palantir Foundry offers a powerful solution: instead of forcing every application, report, and integration to connect separately to ECC and S/4HANA, organizations can use Palantir as a single harmonized data layer across both systems.

This creates a “digital twin” of the enterprise that abstracts away the differences between ECC and S/4, providing unified access to operational and analytical data without redundant maintenance.

How Palantir Helps Reduce Interim Dual Maintenance Costs

1. Unified Data Model for ECC and S/4

Palantir can connect directly to both ECC and S/4HANA systems (via SAP connectors, OData services, or data extracts) and harmonize the key master and transactional data - customers, materials, vendors, G/L accounts into a single, consistent data model.

Example: Instead of maintaining customer hierarchies in both ECC and S/4, Palantir can ingest them from ECC and apply transformation logic that reflects the new S/4 model. Downstream systems (analytics, planning, compliance) can consume the Palantir layer directly, avoiding the need to replicate changes twice.

Impact: Reduces data duplication and manual harmonization efforts by up to 60–70% during migration.

2. Process Continuity Through Digital Twins

Palantir’s Operational Data Layer (ODL) enables enterprises to create a digital twin of critical business processes  such as order-to-cash or supply chain flows  across ECC and S/4 boundaries.

Example: Imagine a company where Europe has migrated to S/4 but North America is still on ECC. Orders may flow from ECC customers to S/4 production plants. Instead of building and maintaining multiple custom SAP interfaces, Palantir can serve as the process bridge — integrating order, inventory, and delivery data in real-time to ensure seamless visibility and coordination.

Impact: Cuts custom integration and reconciliation costs while ensuring consistent KPIs across regions.

3. Harmonized Analytics Layer

Reporting is one of the biggest pain points during phased migration. Palantir provides a centralized analytics layer where ECC and S/4 data can be combined, transformed, and visualized using the same semantic logic.

Example: Finance teams can view a consolidated P&L across both systems without reconciling chart of accounts manually. Palantir’s ontology layer standardizes financial attributes (cost centers, profit centers, etc.) across systems, enabling consistent reporting months  or years  before full migration completes.

Impact: Eliminates need for maintaining dual SAP BW or SAC models during rollout.

4. Accelerated Master Data Migration

By connecting to both source (ECC) and target (S/4) systems, Palantir can simulate and validate master data transformations in advance. This reduces rework during each migration wave.

Example: For materials management, Palantir can pre-map ECC material master attributes to S/4’s simplified data model, identify inconsistencies, and validate against business rules all without touching production systems.

Impact: Reduces downtime and errors during each cutover, saving time and resources.

5. Continuous Value Delivery During Transition

Palantir’s modular architecture allows business users to build analytics and decision applications that remain valid even after the migration is complete. This protects investments in data products and dashboards, reducing re-implementation costs post-S/4 go-live.

Illustrative Scenario: A Global Manufacturing Company

Context: A global manufacturer is migrating from ECC to S/4HANA over 4 years. Europe goes live first, while APAC and North America remain on ECC.

Challenges:

  • Global financial consolidation required across mixed systems

  • Duplicate master data maintenance in multiple systems

  • Integration pain for global supply chain visibility

Palantir Solution:

  • Build a unified Palantir data model integrating ECC and S/4 data

  • Create operational dashboards for global supply chain using this harmonized data

  • Maintain a single master data governance workflow through Palantir’s ontology layer

Outcome:

  • 50% reduction in IT maintenance costs during rollout

  • Single version of truth for finance and operations

  • Seamless reporting continuity across systems

In essence, Palantir allows you to “run as one” even while you’re still migrating to one.

#SAP #S4HANA, #Palantir, #DigitalTransformation, #CloudTransformation, #DualMaintenance, #SAPMigration, #EnterpriseMigration, #ERPStrategy, #BusinessTransformation #ERPTraansformation

entry.title: Understanding Seamless Planning
entry.content:
Introduction to Seamless Planning  

Seamless Planning is a new integration paradigm between SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) and SAP Datasphere that unifies planning logic with enterprise-grade data storage and governance. It allows SAC to remain the planning experience and calculation engine while Datasphere becomes the authoritative and governed persistence layer for plan data and master data. This means planning teams can reuse planning data across analytics, data transformation pipelines, and operational applications—without duplicating or exporting data outside of SAC. Modelers can build SAC planning models that physically store their transactional data and public dimensions inside Datasphere. They also have control over whether planning artifacts from SAC are exposed in Datasphere for reuse across Spaces or downstream analytic models.

Technical Architecture

  • Model Metadata & Planning Logic: Planning calculations, version management, and data actions remain defined inside SAC.
  • Fact Data & Dimensions Stored in Datasphere: The planning model’s fact tables and public dimensions are persisted in Datasphere to enable governed reuse and enterprise distribution.
  • Data Exposure from SAC to Datasphere: SAC can expose selected planning objects as read-only Datasphere artifacts, enabling modelers to use these objects in Data Builder or transform them into Analytical Models.

Key Benefits

  • Unified Planning Data: Centralized storage of plan facts and dimensions in Datasphere ensures consistency across systems and workflows.
  • Direct Persistence to Datasphere: Changes made in SAC planning flows are instantly reflected in Datasphere fact tables—no manual exports required.
  • Optimized SAC Resource Usage: Offloading data storage to Datasphere reduces SAC’s memory and storage footprint.
  • Enterprise Reusability & Governance: Datasphere’s modeling and transformation extend to planning data, enabling secure and scalable reuse in the form of analytic models.

This approach eliminates data silos, reduces duplication, and empowers organizations to operationalize planning data across their digital landscape—while preserving SAC’s rich planning experience at the front end.

Prerequisites for Seamless Planning

Before configuring or deploying planning models from SAC to Datasphere, ensure the following system prerequisites are met.

1. SAC Tenant Must Be Running on SAP HANA Cloud

  • SAC must be provisioned on SAP HANA Cloud infrastructure.
  • To verify: Navigate to System → About in SAC and confirm the HANA Cloud version is listed.
  • This ensures compatibility with Datasphere’s storage and modeling architecture.

 2.  Tenant Co-Location and 1:1 Linkage

  • Both SAC and Datasphere tenants must reside in the same SAP data center region.
  • A 1:1 tenant relationship is required—each SAC tenant must be linked to a single Datasphere tenant.
  • This linkage enables SAC to persist planning data directly into Datasphere spaces.
  • This can be done in System à Administration à Tenant Links in both SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere.

3. Consistent Identity Provider (IdP) Configuration

  • It is strongly recommended that both tenants use the same SAML-based Identity Provider (IdP).
  • This ensures consistent user identity mapping across SAC and Datasphere.

4. System Owner Credentials on Both Tenants

  • The tenant linkage process requires authentication using a system owner account on both SAC and Datasphere.
  • This account must have administrative privileges to authorize cross-tenant integration.

5. User Role Assignment in Datasphere Space

    • SAC users who need to create, edit, or expose planning models must be granted appropriate space-level roles in Datasphere.
    • Without these roles, SAC will not be able to write data or expose model objects to the designated Datasphere space.

If any of the above conditions are not met, then Datasphere will not appear as a selectable data storage location in SAC. The  SAP Knowledge Base Article 3515100 highlights certain errors along with their corresponding workarounds.

Workflow for Seamless Planning

1. Create a New Model in SAC: While creating a new Model in SAC, there is an option available to specify the Data Storage Location as a Space within SAP Datasphere.

2. Configure Dimensions and Measures:  The model created with Datasphere persistence layer is created as a Planning Measure based model by default and the data storage location is Datasphere Space as shown in model details.

3. Expose to Datasphere: There is also an additional option in the Model Details to expose the underlying fact table in the chosen Datasphere space. What gets created in Datasphere: When a SAC planning model is configured to store data in Datasphere:

4. What gets created in Datasphere: When a SAC planning model is configured to store data in Datasphere:

  • A Fact object (read-only) becomes visible in the Datasphere Space.
  • A corresponding physical table (sap.sac.<GUID>) is created to store transactional planning data.
  • Any public dimensions used in the model are created in Datasphere as dimension tables and remain shareable across Space.

5. Execute Planning scenarios in SAC: With the new model now exposed in Datasphere, key planning scenarios can continue to be executed within SAC exactly as before. Seamless Planning does not alter the way SAC planning processes run; it simply extends the option to persist and integrate data through Datasphere while maintaining the familiar SAC planning experience.

  • Create and Execute a Data Action: Develop a Data Action in SAC to update planning data. Once executed, publish the updated data back to Datasphere to ensure synchronization across platforms.
  • Conduct Actual vs Plan Analysis: Utilize SAC's analytical capabilities to compare actual performance against planned figures. This enables variance analysis and supports informed decision-making.
  • Extend Modelling in Datasphere: Build custom calculations directly within SAP Datasphere using the exposed model. Create a dedicated view and Analytical Model on top of these calculations, then visualize the results seamlessly in SAC for enhanced planning insights.

Important Considerations

SAP is actively working to reduce the space dependency in future releases, for latest updates please refer the SAP Roadmap Explorer and the help guide.

  • Cross-Model Planning Constraints: Currently all models involved in cross-model planning operations—such as a data action, cross-model copy step must be in the same Datasphere space.
  • Shared Public Dimensions:  Sharing public dimensions across multiple models is only supported when both the models and the associated public dimensions are deployed within the same SAP Datasphere space. The same requirement applies to currency rate tables, which must reside in the same space to be referenced across models.
  • Hierarchies:  Hierarchies defined in SAP Analytics Cloud are not exposed to SAP Datasphere. If hierarchical structures are required for modeling or reporting, Datasphere modelers must reconstruct these hierarchies natively within Datasphere, ensuring alignment with the underlying data model and semantic layer.

Seamless Planning in BDC

SAP is introducing a unified enterprise planning paradigm through SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC). This represents the next stage in the evolution of Seamless Planning, where planning activities are connected, real-time, and driven by trusted operational data—eliminating the traditional “export, transform, and import” workflow. Because SAC and Datasphere are core components of BDC, seamless planning is highly relevant in this context and establishes the foundation for deep integration of planning data within the BDC environment. Looking ahead, BDC has the potential to further enrich seamless planning by:

  • Supporting planning-enabled intelligent applications that combine analytics with actionable planning workflows.
  • Extending planning architectures to include platforms such as SAP Databricks.
  • Enabling the consumption of data products directly within planning processes, ensuring governed, reusable, and scalable planning assets.

To understand Seamless Planning in context of Business Data Cloud, please refer to this blog.

entry.title: Link SAC and SAP DSP tenants via Formation to Schedule a SAC Story Based on SAP DSP Live Connection
entry.content:
Create a Formation to Integrate with SAP Analytics Cloud

Prerequisites

  • You are an SAP global account administrator, or you are a system landscape administrator.

  • SAP Analytics Cloud can run on Hana 2.0 or HANA Cloud.

  • Both SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants must be located in the same data center and deployed in the same landscape. SAP data centers are not in the scope.

  • Both SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants must use the same identity provider (IdP) and the same subject name identifier.

  • Ensure the relevant SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants or systems in your landscape are available to be integrated in a formation.

  • Context

    A formation is created in SAP BTP cockpit in the System Landscape section of your global account. The formation identifies the systems that can connect with your SAP Analytics Cloud tenant.

    Formations enable the automated integration between a set of your provisioned SAP systems.

    Procedure

    1. In the SAP BTP cockpit System Landscape  Systems page, browse the systems in your customer system landscape.
      Every SAP Analytics Cloud system and SAP Datasphere system you are going to include in this formation must not be apart of another formation. The system landscape features auto-discovered systems in the list.
      • Note

        if a given system is missing on the Systems page, it may be associated with a different customer ID on the SAP BTP global account you're working in. In this case you need to add the system manually, and then register it. For more information, see Adding, Registering, and Deregistering Systems.

    2. Go to System Landscape   Formations. Select Create Formation.
      1. In the General Information step, enter a descriptive formation name.
      2. In the Formation Type drop-down menu, select Integration with SAP Analytics Cloud.
    3. Select Next Step.
    4. In the Include Systems step, select the SAP Datasphere tenant and SAP Analytics Cloud tenant you want to link with.
    5. Select Next Step.
    6. Review your selections and create the formation.

    Results

    The formation appears under your list of formations and a Ready success message is shown.

    Delete a Formation in SAP BTP Cockpit

    Context

    When you delete a formation, the following happens. Both SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants will be excluded from the formation. Then, the subaccount is unassigned. Finally, the SAP Analytics Cloud formation is removed from the Formations page completely.

    Procedure

    1. In the SAP BTP cockpit go to System Landscape  Formations.
    2. Select the formation of SAP Analytics Cloud that you want to remove.
    3. Select Delete at the top-right of the formation.

    Recreation of Formation

    When formation is recreated the scheduling feature will be enabled again. The functionalities will continue to work as they were before the deletion. For scheduling, UCL formation will only provide enablement of tunneled connections.

    As a next step to create Tunnel connection and perform scheduling of SAC story based on DSP live connectivity please follow the help document. 

    https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ANALYTICS_CLOUD/18850a0e13944f53aa8a8b7c094ea29e/1c4c615f5d7f4b78a5ae681759a55650.html?version=2025.23

entry.title: Scheduling SAP Analytics Cloud Stories Based on SAP Datasphere Live Connections
entry.content:
Overview

(Available Starting QRC4 2025)

Scheduled publications are an important feature in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), enabling organizations to distribute stories at regular intervals for offline access over email email delivery.

As SAP Datasphere continues to be the strategic data foundation for SAP customers, many organizations rely extensively on live connections between SAC and Datasphere. Starting with SAP Analytics Cloud QRC4 2025, customers can now schedule publications for stories built on SAP Datasphere live connections.

This capability is supported for:

  • SAP Analytics cloud and SAP Datasphere on BDC Tenant
  • Standalone (non-BDC) SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere Tenant

Prerequisites

To schedule a story based on a Datasphere live connection, the story must use an SAP Datasphere Tunnel Connection.

Creating a Datasphere Tunnel Connection

A Tunnel Connection can be created only when SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants are “deep linked.” Deep linking ensures seamless authentication, metadata access, and cross-system operations.

Deep linking configurations:

  • Option 1 — In BDC tenant where SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere tenants are linked via BDC formation (Recommended)
  • Option 2 — In SAP Analytics Cloud tenant and SAP Datasphere tenant (Non BDC) are linked via UCL formation.  (Recommended) - Refer to blog Link SAC and SAP DSP tenants via Formation to Schedule a SAC Story Based on SAP DSP Live Connection 
  • Option 3 — SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere Tenant are linked for seamless planning as below 

     

Once any one of the above configurations is done, In SAP Analytics Cloud tenant, you can create a SAP Datasphere Tunnel connection using below step

  • From the side navigation, choose Connections  
  • Click Add + Connection
  • Expand Connect to Live Data and select SAP Datasphere.
  • In the dialog, enter a name and description for your connection.
  • From the Connection Type drop-down list, select Tunnel
    • Tunnel connection type is mandatory if you plan to use this Scheduled Publications using the Datasphere Live connection.
    • For tunnel connections, ensure both SAC and Datasphere users use the same Identity Provider (IdP)

Note: In QRC4.2025, you have an option to create new Tunnel connection, however, you will not be able to convert existing SAP Datasphere Direct connection to Tunnel connection. However, if you are on Fast track tenant and SAP Analytics Cloud version 2025.23 or beyond then you can edit Direct connection to Tunnel Connection. If you are on QRC tenant, then this will be available in QRC1.2026

 

Scheduling a Story Based on a Datasphere Live Connection

Once the Tunnel Connection is created and used in the story, it can be scheduled like any other SAC story, with support for email distribution, CSV/Excel/PDF/PowerPoint output, recurrence, dynamic time filters, and personalization.

Conclusion

Starting QRC4 2025, this enhancement supports Scheduling Publication of SAP Analytics Cloud story capabilities for customers using SAP Datasphere with SAP Analytics Cloud.

entry.title: Positioning SAP Business Data cloud on SAP Business Technology Platform : Clearing the Confusion
entry.content:
As we all know, with digital transformation and the move toward cloud mindset, clean core, fit-to-standard, and fit-to-suite, the shift to cloud-based business solutions keeps growing. Many of us remember the term introduced around 2011 when the HANA database was introduced  the SAP Business Intelligence portfolio. Over time, this evolved to BW on HANA, BW/4HANA, and then the ERP transition from ECC to S/4HANA.

From my understanding, this Business Intelligence portfolio or SAP BI Suite has also evolved with the adoption of the cloud platform. Now we hear the term SAP Business Suite, which I think is similar to the earlier BI Suite which acts like an umbrella covering the core enterprise applications. This newer SAP Business Suite connects different areas of the business using SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Business Data Cloud, all running on top of SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).

SAP BTP is known as a platform-as-a-service used to design, build, deploy, and manage end-to-end applications in the cloud. It provides the foundation for integrating, extending, and innovating across SAP and non-SAP systems, so business processes remain connected, flexible, and intelligent.

We are also familiar with the fact that we can view all the services available on BTP through the SAP Discovery Center under different capability areas: App Development, Integration, Data & Analytics and Artificial Intelligence.

If you go to the Discovery Center and look under Data & Analytics, you will see SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) and SAP Datasphere listed there. But when you go to the BTP Cockpit and try to create a service for these applications, you won’t find them.

And that’s exactly where the confusion started for me. Because they appear under BTP capabilities, the expectation is that we should be able to create them as services.
But we can’t and this is where SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) comes into the picture.

 

 

 

 

 

SAP Business Data Cloud is a SaaS business solution suite built on top of BTP. It uses the underlying BTP data and analytics capabilities like Datasphere and SAC.

To simplify:

  • BDC is not replacing BTP — it runs on top of it.
  • BDC is a packaged business solution, not a developer service.
  • You cannot create BDC service on BTP like you create HANA Cloud or Integration Suite.
  • BDC has its own onboarding and tenant provisioning process.

In short, BTP is the platform, and BDC is the ready-to-use data and analytics solution built on that platform.

The next question that popped into my mind, since we cannot create them as services or subscriptions via BTP, how do we access them? We still have a standalone SAC tenant , a standalone Datasphere tenant and we could switch between them easily by linking the tenants. This still works the same.

What changed now is that SAP now sells this as a packaged solution under BDC.
Instead of separate licenses for SAC and Datasphere, BDC combines them into one SaaS package and just one license.

So BTP remains the platform under the hood, while BDC provides the SAAS packaged solution but it is not a BTP service. It has its own onboarding, which I’ll cover in my next blog.

entry.title: Simple understanding of Hierarchies in SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics– Part 1 (Basics)
entry.content:
Accurate CDS hierarchy modeling and understanding is critical for financial reporting and operational analytics. Without well-defined hierarchies, drill-down analysis and aggregated insights become challenging. This blog demystifies hierarchy concepts in SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics and shows how they power SAC,Multidimensiona Reports , AFO and Datasphere scenarios.This blog will give you the basic understanding of Hierarchies in CDS Views (S4 Hana)

What This Blog Covers

  • Common hierarchy terminologies
  • Types of hierarchies in CDS Views
  • Standard hierarchies in S/4HANA
  • Why custom hierarchies matter


1. Key Terminologies-

Before diving into implementation, let’s clarify the basics:

  • Root Node : Top-most node in the hierarchy. Has No parent. Signifies the Hierarchy Structure and contains the Hierarchy metadata. A hierarchy can have several root nodes.
  • Hierarchy Node : Represents a group or element in the hierarchy.
  • Parent Node : A node that has child nodes beneath it.
  • Child Node : Belongs to a parent node.
  • Leaf Node : Lowest node in the hierarchy (end point).
  • Hierarchy Directory : Stores hierarchy definitions.
  • Siblings : Nodes sharing the same parent.
  • Hierarchy Level : Indicates depth of a node in the hierarchy. Levels can be defined as 0,1,2,3 . In S/4 EA change level based hierarchies to Parent child hierarchies .
  • Recursive Hierarchy: Nodes can reference themselves (e.g., Org Structure). Implemented using self-association in CDS.
  • Hierarchy Node Texts: These contain the descriptive names or labels associated with the hierarchy nodes, typically derived from the related master data (for example, the name or description of a General Ledger account or Product Hierarchy Description).
  • Orphan nodes, These are the nodes missing a link to a root. You can choose to ignore them, raise an error, or promote them as alternative roots using annotations like ORPHANS = ROOT

2. Example of a Hierarchy-

Company → Product Category → Product → Variant Shoe Model 1

Example:

  • Company (ABC Corp)  → Root Node -> The top most node in hierarchy (Defined via Hierarchy Directory and Root node has no parent defined)---- To be discussed in details in another Part 2.
  • Product Category (Footwear)  → Child of Company->A Parent Node for Product but this is not the Root node(Since it has Company as a Parent Node).
  • Product (Shoes)  → Child of Product Category->Parent Node for Variant
  • Variant (Shoe Model 1)  → Leaf Node->Lowest Node in the hierarchy

 In SAP: For Cost Center or Profit Center hierarchy, Controlling Area could be the root node.

3. Types of Hierarchies in CDS Views-

In S/4HANA Embedded Analytics, hierarchies are modeled using CDS annotations. Most common type:

  • Parent-Child Hierarchy 🔗 Always recursive. Each node references its parent, forming a tree structure. Example: Cost Center hierarchy where each cost center belongs to a higher-level.

 

  • Level-Based Hierarchy 🔗Not supported in S4 Hana Embedded analytics as Analytical engine supports only Parent Child Hierarchy for drill downs and aggregations.

CDS Annotation Example:

@Hierarchy.parentChild:
{ recurse:          {   parent: 'ParentNode',   child:  'HierarchyNode'   },
  siblingsOrder:    {   by: 'SequenceNumber',    direction: 'ASC'   },
  directory:        '_Hierarchy' }

4. Standard Hierarchies in S/4HANA-

SAP delivers several predefined hierarchies:

  • Cost Center Hierarchy – For controlling and cost reporting
  • Profit Center Hierarchy – For profitability analysis
  • GL Account Hierarchy – For financial statements
  • Product Hierarchy – For material classification
  • EHS Location Hierarchies – For Environment, Health & Safety compliance

5. Custom Hierarchies-

Business requirements often demand custom hierarchies:

  • Example: A sales region hierarchy combining geography and product lines.
  • Implemented using CDS Views by developing a relation between Dimension Views and Hierarchy View.

6. Why Hierarchies Matter?

  • Enable drill-down reporting in SAC or Fiori Multidimensional Reports/AFO.
  • Support aggregations at multiple levels
  • Provide flexibility for planning and analytics

7. Technical Details: Where Hierarchies Are Stored-

  • HRRP_NODE_N Table: Stores Parent Node info, hierarchy node level details, and relationships between nodes(Example where GL Account/Profit Center/Cost Center Hierarchy details are stored).
  • HRRP_DIR_N Table: Stores Hierarchy Directory info (name, version, metadata).

👉When you activate or create a hierarchy (standard or custom), these tables are updated.

  • HRRP_NODE_N = Node-level details (Parent-Child relationships)
  • HRRP_DIR_N = Directory-level details (Hierarchy header info)

8. Hierarchy Components & Annotations-

  • A well-defined hierarchy in CDS has multiple views:

Source(Master Data) View: Provides key fields and relationships (Eg GL Account/Cost Center/Product related details).
Hierarchy View: Contains the relationships and parent–child links. Eg - Hierarchy(Child) Node, Parent Node, Node levels etc.
Directory View: Provides metadata about hierarchy variants -- Optional.
Text Views for labeling nodes and directory entries . Eg: GL account and it's text/ Cost center and it's text etc.

Proper annotations (@Hierarchy.parentChild, @ObjectModel.dataCategory: #HIERARCHY) control recursion, sibling order, orphan handling, and directory association

Notes:

  • Parent–Child Hierarchy: Supported in CDS for analytics; recursive structure.
  • Level-Based Hierarchy: Not supported in CDS for analytical consumption (only parent–child works for drill-down).
  • Orphan nodes = Nodes without a parent.
  • A Parent Node can have multiple Hierarchy Nodes/Child nodes but a hierarchy node cannot have multiple parents
  • A node can appear under different parents in different hierarchy versions, not in the same hierarchy( It usually refers to alternate hierarchy versions or variants, not simultaneous parents in the same hierarchy. For example:

Hierarchy Variant/Version 1: Region → Country → City

Hierarchy Variant/Version 2: Sales Channel → Country → City.This is managed via Hierarchy Directory.

  • A CDS hierarchy cannot serve as the underlying source for building another CDS hierarchy.

Next Article (Part 2)

  • How to activate Standard hierarchies and develop Custom Hierarchies in CDS Views (S4 Hana EA).
  • How to consume hierarchies in SAC

entry.title: Les rôles essentiels du consultant SAP : un acteur clé de la transformation digitale
entry.content:
1. Comprendre les besoins de l’entreprise

Le rôle premier d’un consultant SAP est l’analyse fonctionnelle.
Il doit comprendre les processus métier de l’entreprise : achats, approvisionnements, finance, logistique, production…
Ensuite, il traduit ces besoins en solutions SAP.

"C’est le pont entre les équipes métier et la technologie".

2. Configurer et personnaliser le système SAP

Le consultant paramètre SAP pour qu’il reflète les processus internes de l’entreprise.
Cela inclut :

la configuration des paramètres (ex. : types de documents, règles de prix, schémas logistiques) ;

la personnalisation selon les besoins clients ;

l’optimisation des flux existants.

 

" Il ne code pas, mais configure le système pour qu’il fonctionne comme l’entreprise le souhaite."

3. Assurer l’intégration entre modules

SAP est un système modulaire : MM, SD, FI, CO, PP, etc.
Le consultant doit garantir que les flux circulent correctement entre les modules.

Exemple :
Un flux d’achat en MM doit automatiquement générer des écritures comptables en FI.

 "Il assure la cohérence globale du système."

4. Tester la solution (cycles de tests)

Avant la mise en production, le consultant :

prépare les scénarios de test,

 

exécute les tests unitaires,

accompagne les utilisateurs dans les tests intégrés (UAT).

"l valide que tout fonctionne correctement"

 

 5. Former les utilisateurs

Un système SAP bien configuré n’a aucune valeur si les utilisateurs ne savent pas l’utiliser.
Le consultant prépare :

des supports de formation,

des tutoriels,

des sessions de formation pratiques.

"Il aide les équipes métier à devenir autonomes."

 

 6. Support et résolution des incidents

Après le go-live, le consultant continue d'accompagner l’entreprise :

résolution de bugs,

améliorations continues,

adaptation à de nouveaux besoins.

"l est un partenaire de long terme pour l’entreprise."

 

 7. Veille technologique et évolution du système

SAP évolue constamment, notamment avec S/4HANA et les applications Fiori.
Le consultant doit se tenir à jour pour proposer :

des améliorations,

des innovations,

des solutions plus performantes.

Le consultant SAP est un acteur stratégique qui combine :
 expertise métier
 compréhension technique
 capacité d’analyse
 communication et pédagogie
gestion de projet

Il joue un rôle essentiel dans la digitalisation, l’optimisation et l’efficacité opérationnelle de l’entreprise.

SAP ERP MM (Materials Management) MAN Material Requirements Planning

entry.title: BW Note Validation in SAC: Instantly see whether your BW backend is up to date
entry.content:
Keeping your BW system up to date ensures that you get the most out of your SAC stories designed with BW Live connections. To make full use of the latest SAC innovations, enhancements, and fixes, it is recommended to update your BW support package at least once a year as outlined in SAP Note 2541557. Applying the relevant note collections through the SAP BW Note Analyzer also helps maintain smooth compatibility and performance.

For those wondering whether their BW system is aligned with SAC, there is now an easy way to check. SAC displays a clear status message in the story edit mode and within the support agent. This helps to quickly see if your connected BW system is in sync with the current SAC recommendations or if it needs attention.

What is BW Note Validation

BW Note Validation checks the BW system information returned by your live connection and compares it with SAP’s guidance to determine if the BW system needs to be upgraded. It summarizes the result in two ratings:

  • QRC version rating: how your BW backend aligns with the current SAC quarterly release cycle guidance.
  • Support Package (SP) rating: whether your BW system’s support package level meets minimum recommended levels.

The ratings are shown as status icon and text details so you can immediately see if everything is fine, if an update is recommended, or if the system is out of date.

Where you can see it

  • Support Agent:
    • After recording: When you complete a Support Agent recording, the result view includes BW Note Validation with QRC and SP ratings for the BW systems involved in the session.
      BW Note Validation in Support Tool (recording)
    • When loading an SST file: If you load an SST file into the Support Agent, the validation runs on the captured environment and displays the ratings.
      BW Note Validation in Support Tool (playback)
  • Story Info panel (edit mode): In a story that uses live BW connections, open the Info panel while in edit mode to see the BW Note Validation ratings. This helps story designers quickly confirm their bw backend is up to date or needs attention.
    BW Note Validation in Info Panel

What the ratings mean

  • Up to date: Your BW system meets or exceeds the current guidance for the active SAC installation.
  • Good: Your BW system is in a good condition, but new releases are available.
  • Acceptable: Your BW system is functional, but lags recommended levels; consider scheduling an update.
  • Critical: Your BW system is below supported guidance; an update is strongly advised to avoid issues.

Typical workflows

  • In Support Agent recording mode:
    • Start a recording and reproduce the scenario.
    • After stopping the recording, you will have a link with “More information”.
    • This will open a popup showing the ratings for systems found in your workflow.
  • In Support Agent playback mode
    • In the playback tab, load an existing SST.
    • If this file includes information about the BW ratings, you will see a link saying, “Note status”.
    • Clicking this will open a popup showing the ratings for systems found in your recording.
  • In a Story (edit mode):
    • Open your story that uses a live BW model.
    • Open the Info panel.
    • In the “Issues” tab you can find the information about the BW system ratings in the “Story” section.

Scope and prerequisites

  • BW Note Validation applies to BW live connections used by SAC stories.
  • The feature relies on BW system metadata available to SAC via the live connection.
  • If a story uses multiple BW connections, you will see a rating per connection.
  • Non-BW sources are not included in this validation.
  • Ratings are informative; they do not block usage. Stories remain usable even when the backend is rated Critical.

Release timeline

  • Support Agent display: SAC QRC1.2026.
  • Story Info panel display: SAC QRC1.2026.
  • SAP Note 3554618, "BW InA: SAC BW InA Support Tool"

Why it matters

BW Note Validation gives authors and support teams instant visibility into backend status, reducing the time spent on manual checks and helping you proactively plan updates. It also adds valuable context when investigating issues via the Support Agent, so you can quickly rule in—or out—backend version alignment as a contributing factor.

We’d love your feedback

Try BW Note Validation when it becomes available in your tenant and let us know what you think. Also please share questions and suggestions here, we are happy to help.

entry.title: The Future of Amusement Parks: How SAP Powers the Next Wave of Thrill & Technology
entry.content:
The Future of Amusement Parks: How SAP Powers the Next Wave of Thrill & Technology

When I attended the SAP Top Architect Bootcamp, I expected to deepen my understanding of SAP solutions—and I certainly did. But what surprised me was how often my thoughts drifted back to the world I live in every day: the amusement-park industry, where I’ve spent the past two years shaping experiences, studying operations, and watching how technology transforms guest expectations.

As a mother, my visits to theme parks with my son have also given me a unique, personal perspective. Watching his excitement, his curiosity, and how he interacts with attractions helped me see first-hand how the future of theme parks must evolve.

So, with every SAP capability I explored—across CX, analytics, BTP, AI, and sustainability—I couldn’t help but imagine: What would the theme park of the future look like for me and my son?

  1. Personalised Guest Experiences — The Magic of SAP CX

The Story Begins:

The moment my son and I scan our tickets, our park experience transforms.

My phone buzzes with a personalised route suggestion—highlighting shorter queues, shaded rest spots, and our favourite attractions. Meanwhile, my son receives a notification from his wearable wristband inviting him to meet his favourite character nearby. This hyper-personalised experience is powered by SAP CX.

  • Builds rich guest profiles for both adults and children, tailoring our journey. We can enhance the same using SAP Customer Data Platform - https://www.sap.com/products/data-cloud/customer-data-platform.html which seamlessly integrates into a 360° customer profile.
  • Sends AI-driven recommendations—like a quiet snack zone when kids need a break. This can be leverage with SAP Emarsys - https://www.sap.com/products/crm/emarsys.html  as  it offers personalised suggestions
  • Personalised bundles for families, child-specific deals, and dynamic pricing. This can be achieved  SAP Commerce Cloudhttps://www.sap.com/india/products/crm/commerce-cloud.html.
  • Smooth, intuitive interfaces across mobile and wearables. SAP Build Apps ( https://www.sap.com/india/products/technology-platform/low-code-app-builder.html) and Spartacus (https://community.sap.com/t5/crm-and-cx-blog-posts-by-members/introduction-to-spartacus/ba-p/13418581) can help us to build intuitive interfaces.

For families like ours, this means a day that feels designed just for us.

  1. Immersive AR/VR Worlds — Powered by SAP BTP

The Adventure Expands:

As my son and I stroll through the enchanted forest zone, he suddenly gasps. A digital dragon appears—hovering above us, reacting to his movements and responding to his excitement. He chases it playfully, and the AR storyline adapts in real time to his reactions.

That magic is orchestrated by SAP BTP:

  • Ensuring AR storytelling adapts to our real-world location . SAP Event Mesh can be used to achieve the same(https://www.sap.com/products/technology-platform/integration-suite/capabilities/event-mesh.html)
  • Links my son’s wearable profile so the experience feels personal. SAP Integration Suite can be used for personalised and dynamic experience.(https://www.sap.com/products/technology-platform/integration-suite.html)
  • Behind the scenes, analytics help the park understand which experiences engage you most, enabling continuous optimization of these immersive zones and this can be achieved by SAP Analytics Cloud (https://www.sap.com/products/data-cloud/cloud-analytics.html).    

These immersive experiences create unforgettable moments—for children and adults alike.

  1. Intelligent Park Operations — AI, IoT & Automation at Work

As my son and I enjoy our day, SAP technology silently ensures everything runs flawlessly.

  • Monitoring of ride safety in real time, giving parents like me peace of mind .SAP IoT(https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_IoT/fffd6ca18e374c2e80688dab5c31527f/3c61bd1bedc4473fbd952e92b5e7cf8d.html) sensors monitor ride performance in real time, ensuring that everything operates at peak performance.
  • Technicians use AR-guided repairs to minimize downtime which can be managed by SAP Field Service Management (https://www.sap.com/india/products/scm/field-service-management/what-is-field-service-management.html).
  • AI ensures enough staff are available at family-heavy zones. SAP SuccessFactors  - https://www.sap.com/india/products/hcm.html.
  • Streamlines operations so staff can focus on guest care. SAP Build Process Automation can be used for automating the manual processes.https://www.sap.com/india/products/technology-platform/process-automation/features.html

This invisible intelligence creates a smoother, safer experience—especially for families with young children.

  1. Sustainability at the Core — Enabled by SAP’s Green Solutions.

As we walk, I feel proud showing my son how the park embraces sustainability. Showing him recycling stations that are intelligently placed based on crowd flow, solar panels integrated into ride structures, and sustainable materials used in the food packaging and merchandise, enhance my son’s understanding of sustainability.

SAP can helps us to enable this shift by using products like 

  • SAP Sustainability Control Tower (https://www.sap.com/india/products/scm/sustainability-control-tower.html) for environmental analytics
  • SAP Responsible Design & Production  (https://www.sap.com/india/products/scm/responsible-design-and-production.html) for greener materials
  • SAP Waste Management  (https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ERP/8a399f5444164440ac4f426e847ec901/7567bd534f22b44ce10000000a174cb4.html) powered by IoT.
  • SAP Green Ledger (https://www.sap.com/india/products/financial-management/green-ledger.html) tying sustainability to financial accountability.

This creates a park not just fun—but responsible.

  1. Data as the Heartbeat of the Connected Park

For families like mine, the magic is seamless—but behind the scenes, data orchestrates is everything. Every twist, turn, and laugh in the park is driven by data. You might not see the data at work, but it’s there, ensuring the best possible experience for you, every step of the way.

From real-time ride performance to the preferences of every guest, SAP can be used to unify data, ensuring that everything works in harmony.

SAP’s data-driven approach can be helpful every part of the park:

  • All guest and operational data is integrated into one foundation, enabling real-time, personalised experiences. SAP Datasphere ( https://www.sap.com/products/data-cloud/datasphere.html ) can be leverage for the same 
  • Systems like ticketing, AR/VR, and mobile apps needs to work seamlessly together to create a unified digital experience and this can be managed  by SAP Integration Suite (https://www.sap.com/products/technology-platform/integration-suite.html)
  • Predictive analytics help the park optimize everything from crowd flow to ride performance, ensuring an efficient and exciting day for all visitors. Here we can use SAP Analytics Cloud (https://www.sap.com/products/data-cloud/cloud-analytics.html) to help to do Predictive analytics.
  • Advanced AI models forecast guest behaviour, allowing the park to continuously enhance experiences and predict future trends. SAP AI Core (https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/serviceCatalog/sap-ai-core) can be leveraged for the same.

🌟 The Future of Fun, Built on SAP — For Families, For Dreamers, For Everyone

As my son and I leave the park, tired but smiling, I realise this is what the next generation of amusement parks must deliver—a world where operational excellence, cutting-edge technology, and deeply personal experiences collide.

entry.title: Support of Working Day Calendar in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
Background

A Working Day, also known as Business Day or Factory Day, is an official work day. And the working day calendar, if compared with standard calendar, it will exclude the weekends (Saturday and Sunday) together with national holidays.

In SAP Analytics Cloud, there will be some activities need to be scheduled in a recursive way, such as a daily work, a weekly or bi-weekly work. In the past, these activities can be planned using the standard calendar. But the standard calendar can not differentiate between a working day or a non-working day. As a consequence, some un-necessary tasks will be activated and lead to additional house-keeping effort.

Starting from QRC4 2025, working day calendar is now supported in SAP Analytics Cloud. User can now define recurrence settings using a working day calendar. Series based on working day calendars will have no occurrences on non-working days.

How to set up a working day calendar

Before use the working day calendar in the recurrence settings, a working day calendar needs to be defined in advance. Customers need to define their own working day calendars, since different regions may have their own working day calendars. This can be achieved by defining a Date dimension as User-Managed instead of System-Managed dimension. Because by defining a user-managed data dimension, user can add additional properties to that date dimension and use those properties to indicate whether it is a working day or non-working day.

User can create a new property like the below screenshot:

Please make sure the property ID is started with "CAL_WORKING_DAY_" so the system will recognize this property as working day calendar. And then maintain the property for each member. 1 for working days and 0 for non-working days.

 

Customers may ask, does that mean I should modify the Date dimension for all my existing models?

The answer is NO. The related recurrence setting will allow user to select a working day calendar from a different model. This means, user can create a model with working day calendar defined, and reuse that model in different scenarios and related models. Although custom can use an existing model and enhance the date dimension accordingly, but it could be more convenient to create a brand-new model, so the working calendar can be managed centrally without impact existing models. And there's another reason to define a brand-new model. Since reading the working day calendar information from the model will still follow the data access control as a standard model object. A brand-new model under public folder will avoid additional effort for authentication configuration.

For more details about how to set up a working day calendar in a model, please check the related help document:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ANALYTICS_CLOUD/00f68c2e08b941f081002fd3691d86a7/785164b1c1234c5286882ff085e4d23d.html#how-to-set-up-a-working-day-calendar-in-a-model

 

How to use the working day calendar for your series

Currently, the working day calendar can be used in the recurrence setting, which is used in some features, including:

Calendar task, Schedule Publication, Data Change Insight.

Using Calendar task as an example, when create a task which needs to be recursive, the option to use working day calendar will be available.

As shown in the above screenshot, user can set the recurrence patten and select the desired days for working days. User will be able to choose the corresponding model and property created in advance.

If the recurrence pattern is set to week or month, the working day calendar is also available with similar behavior.

Besides the recurrent setting in task design, the working day calendar can also be used in the calendar list view.

In the Gantt Chart Settings, user can also enable showing the calendar with working day calendar.

Once this setting is turned on, the gantt chart display will display the non-working days in grey if there's at least one event loaded in the calendar.

For more details about how to set up recurrence using working day calendar, please check the below online document:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ANALYTICS_CLOUD/00f68c2e08b941f081002fd3691d86a7/785164b1c1234c5286882ff085e4d23d.html#how-to-set-up-recurrence-using-a-working-day-calendar

The settings for Schedule Publication and Data Change Insight will be similar.

You may also check the below demo video as reference.

 

If the above video doesn't work, you may also check it via below link:

https://video.sap.com/media/t/1_byk63fen

 

Thanks a lot and let us know if you have any questions or comments.

best regards, Roy

entry.title: Three "hidden" features in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
SAP Analytics Cloud continues to evolve as a leading platform for analytics, planning and intelligent insights. Yet many users are unaware of the rich set of „hidden“ capabilities that sit beyond the standard functionality. These lesser known features offer meaningful advantages: from improving user experience to simplifying complex workflows. This blog highlights some of SAP Analytics Cloud’s most valuable but often overlooked tools that can significantly enhance how organizations interact with their data.

 

FEATURE 1 - BOOKMARKS

What are Bookmarks in SAP Analytics Cloud?

A Bookmark is a saved state of a story or page. It captures how the page looks at that moment, including – filters you selected, input controls, variable selections, drill levels etc. it’s like taking a snapshot of your story/page settings and not the data itself.

Why are Bookmarks useful?

  • Quickly return to your preferred view – if the story is complex, with many filters and drilldowns, you can setup a view once and refer back to it as needed.
  • Shre personalized views with others – you can create a bookmark and share it with specific users. Each user still has the latest live data not a static snapshot of the data.
  • Reduce user errors – instead of another user trying to recreate the view you have created, you can simply send them a bookmark and they view exactly what you see.

Steps to create a Bookmark:

In View mode: you can Bookmark the current state of a story to quickly return to it. Simply go to

The following screen will open:

You can enter a name and click on Save. Once saved you can check under Open Saved Bookmarks:

This will open the version you’ve bookmarked in View mode, you can still go into Edit mode and edit the bookmarked screen.

 

FEATURE 2 – SMART INSIGHTS

What are Smart Insights?

Smart Insights is an AI powered feature in SAP Analytics Cloud that can save time instead of manually creating reports to quickly view specific data. It helps non-technical users understand data – people who aren't analysts can instantly get a view of the data that they need without having to build a report.

Why are Smart Insights useful?

  • Supports faster decision making – Smart Insights turns raw data into actionable insights.
  • Easy access of information – can quickly check sales for a specific location within your data.

Steps to use Smart Insights:

From Home you can access Smart Insights (Just Ask)

You can also access Smart Insights from

This can be accessed from anywhere in SAP Analytics Cloud as it is pinned to the Toolbar area of SAP Analytics Cloud.

After clicking on the Smart Insights icon you will be taken to this screen:

Click on the “Indexed Acquired Models” dropdown and select your model:

Once you have selected your model, you can start selecting fields from the model you want to see. In this example I will look at Quantity Sold and Location:

Hit enter or click the blue lightbulb and SAP Analytics Cloud will start creating the visualizations for you:

P.S: This can also be viewed as a table and Data Analyzer can be accessed as well.

 

FEATURE 3: COMMENTS AND COLLABORATION

What are Comments in SAP Analytics Cloud?

Comments let you add notes, explanations, discussions or action items directly inside a story or dashboard. It's basically in-story communication, so people don’t need to leave SAP Analytics Cloud to discuss the data.

Why are Comments useful?

  • Keeps conversations in one place – with Comments, the discussion stays right next to the actual data, no context gets lost and no emails need to be sent.
  • Improves collaboration – teams can: ask questions, tag people, provide explanations etc, all directly in the dashboard. It turns dashboards into collaborative tools.
  • Useful for audit trails – Comments create a record of: decisions, discussions, explanations etc. if there is a question on the data months after a decision has been made; there us a clear trail to follow.

Steps to create Comments:

Click on the  in the Toolbar, go to Others and Click on Comment:

Below the Table you will see a Comment Widget loading and appear:

Click on “Click to add Comment”:

 To add in another comment after this click on the comment icon and another comment section will open:

As organizations aim to make more informed, timely decisions, understanding the full breadth of SAP Analytics Cloud’s capabilities becomes increasingly important. The “hidden” features discussed in this blog demonstrate how much more the platform can offer beyond the basics. By integrating these functionalities into your everyday processes, you can create more efficient workflows, more interactive stories and ultimately more impactful analytics. Leveraging these tools ensures you are getting the most out of your SAP Analytics Cloud investment.

entry.title: SAP Certification Is Changing: What You Need to Know About the New Format
entry.content:
If you’ve been following SAP’s certification updates, you’ll know things are changing in a big way. The traditional multiple-choice exams are being replaced with a much more practical approach. I recently went through all the latest materials and sessions about the new SAP certification format, especially for SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), and I want to share what I learned and how you can prepare.

Why Is SAP Changing Its Certification Format?

SAP wants certifications to mean more than just passing a test. The new format is designed to make sure certified professionals can actually do the work required on real SAP projects. Instead of just memorizing theory, you’ll be asked to solve problems and perform tasks that you’d encounter in your day-to-day job. This shift is great news for both candidates and employers. Companies can trust that certified consultants are ready for hands-on work, and candidates can show they’re truly job-ready.

What’s Different About the New Exams?

The biggest change is the move to performance-based assessments. You’ll be asked to complete tasks in a simulated SAP system, or respond to real-world scenarios, sometimes interacting with an AI avatar or submitting a video response. You can use SAP Help Portal, SAP Learning, and even SAP Joule (the AI tool) during the exam, just like you would on a real project. This open-book style makes the exam feel much more like actual work.

You also get to choose how you want to be assessed for some parts: either through an AI role-play or by uploading a video. After you finish, you’ll receive instant feedback, including analytics on your technical depth and communication skills.

Role-Based Certifications and Staying Certified

SAP certifications are now tailored to specific job roles, such as developer, administrator, or architect. This means the exam content is more relevant to what you’ll actually do in your role. Certifications aren’t permanent anymore. You’ll need to complete a “stay-certified” assessment each year to keep your credential active. This helps ensure everyone stays up to date with the latest SAP technology and best practices.

Timeline for the New Format

The rollout starts in November 2025 for selected exams, including SAP BTP Administrator, SAP Build Developer, Solution Architect – SAP BTP, SAP Business Data Cloud, and SAP Generative AI Developer. By 2026, all SAP certifications will use this new practical format.

What Hasn’t Changed?

You’ll still get a digital badge when you pass, and the registration process is the same as before. If you already have a certification, it remains valid, but you’ll need to follow the renewal process to keep it active.

How Should You Prepare?

Focus on building practical SAP skills. Spend time working in SAP simulation environments, and practice explaining SAP solutions clearly and simply. Get comfortable with timed tasks and AI evaluation, and make sure your laptop, internet, webcam, and audio all meet SAP’s technical requirements before exam day.

Spotlight on SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) Certification

The BDC certification is a great example of the new approach. It covers foundational knowledge and practical skills in SAP Business Data Cloud. The assessment includes technical knowledge of BDC, integration with SAP Business Warehouse, SAP Analytics Cloud, SAP Datasphere, and SAP Databricks. To earn the badge, you’ll need to complete the recommended SAP Learning Journey and pass the C_BCBDC exam. Remember to renew your badge every year.

Exam questions breakdown from my attempt:

 

  • Technical Knowledge of BDC (40%)
  • Integration with SAP Business Warehouse (15%)
  • Technical Knowledge of SAP Analytics Cloud (15%)
  • Technical Knowledge of SAP Datasphere (15%)
  • Technical Knowledge of SAP Databricks (15%)

 

Tips for Success

Take your time and use the pause button to think before you answer. Break your responses into clear chunks, and don’t worry about giving too much information, there’s no penalty for being thorough. Read the feedback you get and use it to improve before your next attempt. And don’t rush; you have plenty of time.

Useful Links

Here are some resources that helped me:

  • SAP Certification Overview
  • SAP Certification in the Age of AI
  • SAP BDC Learning Journey
  • SAP Certification BDC

Final Thoughts

SAP’s new certification format is a big step forward. It’s designed to make sure credentials really mean something and that certified professionals are ready for real project work. If you’re preparing for the SAP Business Data Cloud certification, focus on practical skills, clear communication, and continuous learning. The future of SAP certification is here, and it’s all about being ready for the real world.

If you have questions or want to share your experience with the new SAP certification, I’d love to hear from you in the comments.
